261.text: I want another shot, I want another shot.

I head for the kettle, I need tea, dinner

Roy's 22 busts into page 232 - and in doing

283.text:
barrel .20 delving, probing, feeling its way

290.text:
So what does this prove? - well, it shows

294.text:
over 50 shades of grey squirrels. But we don't

298.text:
- thousands of them. So we leave our adult
version of Listen with Mother or Jackanory

303.text:
and concentrate on this evening's airgunning
action.

307.text:
We've been invited to a waste processing unit
in Norfolk to join Ken, Paul and Stu, aka

314.text:
YouTube's KPS Hunters...friends with a passion
for air rifles.

317.text:
Thank you very much for inviting us up here
tonight. You have got the whole Fieldsports

325.text: Channel crew up here so what are we up to.

327.text:
Well tonight we are shooting on the transfer
station and I promise there will be a lot

332.text: There is going to be quite a few are there?

334.text: There is going to be a lot of rats.

Have you got anywhere I can get up and out

337.text:
Yes there is a gantry up there so you can
climb up the gantry.

340.text: No but you can shoot down onto the rubbish.

341.text:
That is fine as long as they are not going
to be running around my legs.

342.text:
No, no. We have had that before and that is
not very nice. There was a lot of screaming

349.text: So what do you reckon numbers wise?

352.text:
Well from previous occasions coming up here
we have got well into double figures. The

358.text: other time we got between 250 and 300 rats.

363.text:
So as soon as you are loading you are firing

370.text: So as long as we can shoot straight.

We will all get in our locations and then
we take it in turns each and get round the

378.text:
I am looking forward to it. If you hear any

384.text:
This site is over run with rats and if anything's
going to show how effective a decent air rifle

389.text: is for pest control this is.

Roy, Mark and Crow are all using pre charged
sub 12ft/lb air rifles. The break barrel is

397.text:

430.text:
This is unbelievable. We have got rats running

453.text:
Do you want that one? Oh my god they are everywhere.
Literally it is thick with them. I have never

462.text:
On the other side of the gantry Crow is having

464.text:
I am having great fun. I could stay all night.
Lucky I don't live closer is all I can say.

I would be here all the time. Does chuck up

474.text:
are lot of rats here, a hell of a lot of rats.
All the time you can hear them running around

you and they are not small they are all big

by the big ones. They are that big. They have
got cats here, but they don't seem to catch

491.text:
many. I think they are too scared. They spend
all their time back in the shed there. Eating

You do get the feeling that it wouldn't matter

So the nightmaster with the RI on it has really

So we are just picking the rats off as we

Roy's also brought along the Webley air pistol.

We have got a .22 pistol that we are just

scope on it so we have got to get reasonably

So hopefully we can get ... well if we can't

able to ever do it and I just want to see
if we can take a couple off with this with

587.text: Yes. That is that. It does work. Excellent.

With hundreds of pellets unloaded into the

It is unbelievable. I have never seen shooting
like this. They are every where. You can't

603.text:
You don't have to bait them, nothing. You

611.text: It is a good night's sport.

As I say I have never seen shooting like this.
It is brilliant, brilliant fun.

617.text: How do you like it, alright?

619.text:
Superb. Thank you for inviting us up it has

624.text: How many have you got do you reckon?

627.text:
I have no idea. We keep shooting. How many

635.text:
This is the fourth time and look how many
rats. Every time over 800

638.text: No, no and you never will.

641.text:
Which is good. People are coming out and really

651.text:
You have got morals ... but I am glad you

654.text:
I have never seen shooting like this. You
can't want to have more fun.

664.text:
It has been a special night. Everyone has
enjoyed some extraordinary sport. In total

670.text:
we probably shot more than 300 rats - and

And if anyone wants a copy of a well thumbed

me a line. We might even get the boys to sign

693.text:
So ratting in a dump in Norwich. Last week
we had Ibex in the mountains of Spain. Still

699.text:
variety is the spice of life. If only there
was more variety in our news readers it is

705.text: David on the Fieldsports Channel News Stump.

718.text:
American shotgun virtuoso Tom Knapp has died
aged 62. The man who revived exhibition shooting

724.text:
in the USA during the 1980s, he was the first
to throw 10 clay targets in the air and blast

730.text:
them all before they could hit the ground.
Sponsored for most of his career by Benelli

734.text: he recently moved to CZ USA.

738.text:
Badminton Horse Trials is on this weekend,
2nd-6th May 2013. The Gloucestershire event

744.text:
is expected to attract a record crowd to watch
riders including Michael Jung, William Fox-Pitt,

749.text:
Andrew Nicholson. Badminton Horse Trials is
the second biggest sporting spectator event

754.text:
in the world after the Indianapolis 500 car
race in the USA.

759.text:
A former soldier Allan Roberts lost both his
legs below the knees in a roadside bomb in

763.text:
Iraq three years ago. Last week, Allan Roberts
the keen shooter joined BLESMA and Help For

770.text:
Heroes supporter Lee Jackson in Wiltshire
to go stalking for two days, which Lee gave

775.text:
Allan for free. Allan is a member of the BLESMA
Trans4mers and a member of the world's first

779.text:
all-amputee skydiving team. Out with Lee,
Allan was delighted to stalk into and shoot

784.text:
two roebuck and his mate Eddie Nash shot a
muntjac.

787.text:
Scottish landowners and gamekeepers are backing
a new initiative to stimulate public interest

793.text:
in hen harriers and provide a better understanding
of one of the "most protected" upland bird

794.text:
species. Members of the public are being asked
to report sightings of hen harriers to help

797.text:
the authorities determine how many are left
and where they can be found.

801.text:
More than 1,000 people, including 200 mounted,
went to the farewell meet of Diana and Maurice

807.text:
Scott, joint masters of the Devon & Somerset
Staghounds. They have together been joint

813.text: masters of the pack for more than half a century.

816.text:
The British skate record has tumbled to a
235lb monster. David Griffiths caught it a

822.text:
mile-and-a-half off the coast of Oban on the
boat Laura Dawn II. Angling Times magazine

827.text:
reports that Welsh specimen hunter took an
hour-and-a-half to haul the 7ft 6inch-long

832.text:
skate up through over 500ft of water while
he was on holiday in Scotland.

838.text:
And finally, a viewer sends us this film.
A friend of his is a gamekeeper who has shot

842.text:
100s of foxes. However, in that soft way we
country people have, he adopted this orphan

848.text:
fox, which gets on famously with his young
terrier - and even betters it in this game

853.text:
of rough and tumble. So much so, maybe it's
time to replace our terriers with foxes�!

858.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

Thank you David - do your tie up. Later we
have got some high-vis night vision foxing,

but first let's see what is going on around
the world in Hallo Charlie.

even through last year's floods. There is

904.text:
fry everywhere. The bigger fish are moving
back into their feeding spots. Some of them

who has never fished before and on the first

932.text:
Hallo Charlie. This week I am at Ronnie Sunshines
the premier air gun store in Berkhamsted.

I am filming the first of my pistol shooting

Younameit to Charlie@fieldsportschannel.tv

973.text:
Thank you one and all - good efforts - keep
'em coming. Next we have got a new series

980.text:
on fox shooting. Outfoxing. Over the coming
weeks we are going to show you the tricks,

984.text:
tips and kit people use to outwit this most
cunning of quarry. This week we are protecting

989.text:
lambs from foxes with our own Little Bow Peep.
It is Roy Lupton.

999.text:
Roy has a new foxing vehicle - inherited from
his mate Brian. The last time we were out

1008.text:
in this beast was the night of the 21 foxes.
That's something we'll be trying to surpass

1013.text:
later this year. Right now it's not the double
figures we're after - just the rogue foxes

1018.text:
that are enjoying the lamb takeaways here
in the South-East of England.

1022.text:
We've already had some success - lying in
wait while combining the whistle with an electronic

1027.text:
Western Rivers Nite Stalker Pro positioned
remotely from us. However, the farmer is still

1032.text:
finding carcases and Roy needs to get a move
on.

1035.text:
Our first port of call is up on the North
Downs where a lot of the problems are concentrated.

Darren is the one shooting tonight. Roy hasn't
recovered from the last bitter night's foxing

1046.text:
and is staying near the relatively luxurious
Land Rover heating vents.

sets of eyes and keeps his camera wide, not

Straight in front, slightly to the right.
There are two there.

The one on the right falls on the spot and
Gary goes to get it. It's a young vixen

1076.text:
Well that is absolutely superb. Darren took
another nice shot there. This is one of the

1081.text:
main places we have been having a lot of trouble.
The foxes have really been hammering the lambs

1084.text:
up here on the hill. That is the seventh fox

1089.text:
week and they are still causing a lot of problems.
The interesting thing is that is the third

1094.text:
vixen we have taken from this field. One of
the vixen was a milking vixen and two have

1100.text:
been barren. So again it just goes to show

this all of the foxes will pile in and you

when you have got a lot of late lambs out
like this they really, really will hit them

1114.text:
hard and obviously when you have got that
many foxes coming in and taking lambs it really

Our second customer is back down the valley

Unfortunately, a little too much. The skyline

a 200-yard shot but Darren executes it well

But can we find it? No we can't. Roy even

wants the place free of all carcases if at

Of course not EVERY fox is going to be eliminated

Lupton always gets his fox - he's now taken
a dozen Charlies off that ground. ... Now

let's talk Aussie rules foxing - our friends

The Aussies, as we know are a competitive

1194.text:

whistle tried to call in a fox as close as

Hmmm - not bad eh!? - even Ron's 96-year-old

Now, we love Australians - we invented them.
But they are a competitive lot. They want

to know if there's any other country out there

can now reveal� oh dear me no� a couple

Well that was amazing footage or are you the

Channel viewership. Send us the videos via

1305.text:
Now if you are the kind of person who has
trouble calling even their dog to heel, you

1309.text:
will want to watch Skinners Gundog training
tips.

1320.text:
How do you communicate with your dog. For
top gundog trainer Howard Kirby, the whistle

1325.text: is essential. It is practically its own language.

1328.text:
A good dog handler particularly a spaniel
handler uses his whistle as little as possible.

1332.text:
The less you do with the whistle the more
the dog does and of course if you have got

1335.text:
somebody in the background constantly shouting
stop, come here, go there, it puts you off.

1340.text:
We want him to get his head down and know
his job. A good trainer teaches him to do

1345.text:
his job. But we have got core whistles we
need. A series of whistles ... tells the dog

1351.text:
to come back that is how we train him. It
doesn't tell him anything we train him to

1354.text:
understand that. We also train the dog when
he hears a single bleep to stop and sit. In

1360.text:
the case of our spaniels there are variation
on this where every you go, we double bleep

1365.text:
to tell the dog to turn, change direction
and come back across us. Single pip to stop,

1371.text:
double pip to turn and a series of pips to
come straight back now. I am using a silent

1375.text:
whistle here there are lots of variations
on whistles. It doesn't matter as long as

1378.text: you are consistent with the whistle.

1379.text:
Do you use different whistles for different
dogs?

1381.text:
Yes I do. As it happens I use this little
silent whistle for my spaniels, because we

1386.text:
are using the whistle quite a lot for turning
the dog. So it keeps the whole volume thing

1389.text:
down and I use this plastic ... whistle on
my retrievers. As I say different people have

1398.text:
different ideas. It really doesn't matter
as long as your dog is familiar with that

1401.text: whistle and that command you give.

1402.text:
Howard Kirby runs Mullenscote Gundogs from
Lains Shooting School near Andover in Hampshire.

1407.text:
Visit Mullenscote.co.uk. This series on gundog
training tips is brought to you by Skinners

1412.text:
Petfoods, maker of the Field & Trial range
of gundog feeds. Visit SkinnersPetfoods.co.uk

1420.text:
Now the sun is coming out and the gun manufacturers
are keen for us to try out their rifles and

1427.text:
Are you a Browning lover? If so, here's what
Browning has on offer this year.

1436.text:
We're at the Browning press launch of two
new shotguns and rifles: an A5 semi-auto shotgun,

1452.text:
a British version of the B725, a new driven
big game rifle called the Maral and a new

1459.text:
GRS stock for the X-bolt rifle. The reptiles
have gathered at the award-winning Ian Coley

1464.text:
Shooting School in Gloucestershire to try
them out. First up, Sporting Shooter editor

1468.text: Dom Holtam finds out about the new A5.

1470.text:
So David we are here today to try the new
Browning A5. It is a very distinctive looking

1478.text: It certainly is. The hump is back.

1479.text:
The hump is back. It has a very distinct hump
back here.

1482.text:
It does. It is a bit like the auto your Grandad
would have shot. The old auto 5 which had

1488.text:
the distinctive hump back. The old auto barrel
recoiled, but on this one it is totally a

1493.text:
different mechanism. What we call a kinomatic
drive. Basically the energy from the shot

1499.text:
is used to drive the gun for the second shot.
It is all done by a string which is in the

1505.text:
bolt. So that is the main difference. The
internals are very simple on this gun and

1508.text:
there is hardly anything to go wrong. That
is why we guarantee it for 100,000 shots.

1511.text:
If you are a serious gamekeeper or a vermin
controller you are using your gun in a professional

1517.text:
capacity and you are not fastidious about
cleaning it then I would recommend the A5

1523.text:
The Mark Gilchrists of this world who are
renowned for not being gentle on equipment

1527.text:
It is a gun for Mark Gilchrist. We nearly
called it the Gilchrist.

1530.text:
Now one of the lovely things about the A5
is the speed loading facility. Need to reload?

1535.text:
It's simple. Just push the cartridges in from
the underneath. You can do it under pressure

1540.text:
and without looking. However, when it comes
to the official press demonstration, it's

1547.text:
Alternatively you can turn it upside down
and use the speed load port. Alternatively

1556.text:
you can turn it upside down and use the speed
loading facility. You literally flick it in

1566.text: Anyone can do it. Even an idiot.

1569.text: Sadly we couldn't find an idiot.

1571.text:
It always happens on camera, doesn't it? Maybe
he'd be better off with the more straightforward

1576.text:
new B725. The Browning boffins listened to
the British and have come up with a new version

1582.text:
that designed to appeal to the UK market.
Here's the verdict from Patrick Tillard of

1589.text:
Yes, we had a great day. We were really lucky
with the weather. Spent most of the day with

1594.text:
the B75, the black model. Been out of practice
for a bit, but it is a nice gun, managed to

1602.text:
get a few. Ground was quite testing. Got harder
as the day went on, but good fun, nice gun.

1607.text:
Having seen today the Browning range that
�2,000 to �4,000 can buy you a nice gun.

1615.text:
On other products, there's a new adjustable
stock for the X-bolt rifle. The big rifle

1619.text:
launch is the Maral, which comes in .308,
.30-06, .300 Win mag and 9.3x63, which you

1626.text:
can see on the Browning stand at the CLA Game
Fair. One thing's for sure, after today's

1631.text:
launches, you will be reading a lot about
these shotguns and rifles in the sporting

1638.text:
Next up it is Hunting YouTube. Not quite as
international as usual, but full of hunting

1642.text: and fishing goodness from the UK and the USA.

1650.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1655.text:
Ever wondered where all those lovely pheasants
and partridges came from? Now BASC has uploaded

1660.text:
the definitive film to tell their story. The
Game Farm shows how game farming can be the

1664.text:
cornerstone of a successful shoot: sophisticated
breeding programmes, careful selection, all

1669.text:
the science and magic that go into producing
fit, happy birds. And we all like fit, happy

1675.text:
Now bringing on pheasants is one thing, but
predator control is another part of the great

1679.text:
shoot equation. Viewer Jason Orock recommends
Prairie Swat Coyote Hunting. We're in South

1684.text:
Dakota with Ben, Gavin, Bo and Nick shooting
coyotes, calling them in just like foxes.

1689.text:
Talking of foxes, let's got back to the high
old days of foxhunting in the 1980s and 1990s.

1694.text:
Fox and Hound action from yesteryear shows
a montage of bolting and running foxes and

1700.text:
To fishing. Viewer Guy Baxendale recommends
Carp Fishing Tips Urban Banx 4 with Alan Blair,

1706.text:
set in Northlands Park, Basildon. Carp fishing
on YouTube is a crowded place but this is

1710.text: easily one of the best channels.

1712.text:
Viewer Nigel Ellis-Gray goes international
with his recommendation: nearly five minutes

1716.text:
of epic rod bending action on the Fraser River,
BC, Canada after monster sturgeon. Nigel says

1722.text:
his son who lives in Vancouver has done this
and calls it one of the great experiences

1728.text:
Sam from SRSPower submits his latest video
'Pigeon Shooting over Oil Seed Rape'. As usual,

1733.text:
it starts with nearly a minute of car driving
but hang in there. It gets to the action:

1737.text:
a good day at his Dad's friend's farm shooting
woodpigeons over oilseed rape.

1744.text:
Finally, Louis from Essex Bushcraft is taken
by UKHunters1's catapult hunt for woodpigeon,

1750.text:
squirrel and even duck. Now, the jury is out
on using catapults on pests and game - and

1755.text:
this video really does nothing to further
the cause as these look like park birds and

1759.text:
animals with no fear of humans until the human
behind this video does for them - but, rest

1763.text:
assured, the Royal Horticultural Society recommends
catapults for garden pests, so they must be

1769.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1772.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,

Well we are back next week when we will be
having a go at muntjac. If you are watching

our programme that is out every Wednesday
7pm UK time. This has been Fieldsports Britain.
